p: Researchers have addressed the variables of pro-environmental behavior in a variety of ways, including focusing on the use of attitudes to induce participatory behaviors [ 28, 30], examining the impact of pro-environment behavioral intentions on students’ background variables (gender, age and experience [ 12]) and studying littering attitudes as a potential moderating variable between personality traits (altruism and locus of control) and pro-environment behavioral intentions [ 30, 49, 50]. Additionally, Simmons and Widmar [ 51] used people’s recycling behaviors and holistic personality traits (e.g., conscientiousness) as main test variables. While participants were highly motivated when situational manipulations of environmental behaviors led to positive feedback, they did not continue practicing these behaviors in everyday life [ 43, 52, 53].
